results.title: Black dogs
results.creator_credit: Andrew Sully, Luigi Acquisto and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: A short Melbourne comedy which explores the complications that arise when a gothic punk woman and her racist skinhead boyfriend move next door to a Vietnamese-Australian couple in Melbourne’s western suburbs. Funny and astute, “Black Dogs” pokes gentle fun at some of the eccentricities of youth subcultures without being patronising or offensive. Sharply written and directed, this gem of a movie manages to entertain as it examines some of the tensions of modern “multicultural” Australia. The acting by the young cast is faultless.

results.title: Black Divaz
results.brief_description: This documentary explores the inaugural Miss First Nations competition and goes beyond the glitz, glue guns and glamour of black drag in an intimate portrait of what it means to be an Indigenous drag queen today.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

results.description: It’s the Miss First Nations competition! Beyond the glitz, glue guns and glamour of black drag to reveal a fun, fabulous and sometimes fearful place. A sassy, intimate portrait of what it means to be an Indigenous drag queen today.
description_for_label: It’s the Miss First Nations competition! Beyond the glitz, glue guns and glamour of black drag to reveal a fun, fabulous and sometimes fearful place. A sassy, intimate portrait of what it means to be an Indigenous drag queen today.

results.title: Black Dahlia
results.brief_description:
Black Dahlia is a suspense thriller based loosely on the unsolved California murder of Elizabeth Short, nicknamed “Black Dahlia” for her favoritism towards black clothing.

The game is a point-and-click puzzle-solving adventure with live action cutscenes. Full 360 degree horizontal and limited vertical panning allow the player to scan each scene with the mouse. Jim’s in-game notebook acts as a journal as it records everything of importance that he has examined.

Black Dahlia has over sixty puzzles dispersed over nearly as many locations. They range in difficulty, style and type including jigsaw, manipulation, code breaking, mazes and object based. Well publicized bypass codes can be used to “auto-solve” them without compromising the game, since no score is kept.

constellations_other.name: Women and crime
constellations_other.description: The allure and fascination of dangerous women and women in danger.

results.description: Taking place in the 1940s, the game puts the player in control of a rookie government agent, Jim Pearson, whose first case involves investigating Nazi propaganda. The case is not as simple as it sounds, however. Before long, Jim uncovers information and evidence that the Nazis have connections to the supernatural, occultism as well as some very bizarre and ritualistic killings. Jim meets Elizabeth Short who possesses a strange engraved stone known as the “Black Dahlia”, an artifact coveted by the Nazis as a source of ultimate power. When her brutal murder occurs, the stone disappears. During Jim’s search for the missing item, he uncovers a web of evil, deceit and intrigue. Will he get out alive .. and uncorrupted?
description_for_label: Taking place in the 1940s, the game puts the player in control of a rookie government agent, Jim Pearson, whose first case involves investigating Nazi propaganda. The case is not as simple as it sounds, however. Before long, Jim uncovers information and evidence that the Nazis have connections to the supernatural, occultism as well as some very bizarre and ritualistic killings. results.title: Black Comedy
results.brief_description: Black Comedy is irreverent, politically incorrect and goes where no other series can go. Featuring a fantastic ensemble cast of Indigenous writers and performers, including many special cameo appearances.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Laughing in the face of adversity
constellations_other.description: Comedy has been used by First Nations storytellers as a tool for social change. On our screens, humour invites audiences to engage with stories and prompts them to grapple with ideas that they otherwise might shy away from.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.description:
A sketch comedy show by Blackfellas… for everyone!

Featuring a fantastic ensemble cast of Indigenous writers and performers and includes many special guest cameo appearances. Meet some of the lively characters including, the Tiddas – two of the most competitive, over the top gay Blackfellas; Mavis the mean-mouthed cleaning woman; the Housewives of Narromine and Deadly Dave who can fix anything. Black Comedy is irreverent, politically incorrect and goes where no other series can go.

results.title: Black cloud over Bali
results.brief_description: In March 1963, Bali’s holy mountain, Gurung Agung, erupted. Over a wide area there was darkness and rain and thousands fled their homes. Molten lava poured down the mountainside killing 1,500 people; 189,000 acres of rice paddy fields were destroyed and a wide area was covered in volcanic ash. Narrated by Denis Mathews.

results.title: Black chicks talking [Widescreen] (A)
results.creator_credit: Leah Purcell, Bain Stewart, SBS Independent and BungaburBungabura Productions
results.brief_description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five very different Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women frankly share their life experiences and opinions. Though their backgrounds are extremely diverse, common themes of culture, family, racism and denial run through their stories, as does the ongoing personal and social legacy of past government polices of forced removal. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity. Teachers notes available through Film Australia at: http://www.filmaust.com.au/programs/default.asp?content=teachers_notes

results.title: Black Chicks Talking
results.brief_description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five dynamic Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today.

constellations_other.name: Women in charge
constellations_other.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

results.description: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five dynamic Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women share their experiences and opinions with extraordinary candour. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity and a celebration of five very different lives.
description_for_label: Performer and writer Leah Purcell talks with five dynamic Indigenous women - Rosanna Angus, Kathryn Hay, Deborah Mailman, Cilla Malone and Tammy Williams - about what it means to be Aboriginal in Australia today. In a series of individual interviews and at one lively dinner party, the women share their experiences and opinions with extraordinary candour. The result is a passionate and challenging exploration of black identity and a celebration of five very different lives.

results.title: Black cat, white cat
results.creator_credit: Emir Kusturica, Karl Baumgartner, Komuna, Pandora Films and CiBy 2000
results.brief_description: Bosnian-born filmmaker, Emir Kusturica, made this farcical comedy set in a Gypsy settlement along the banks of the Danube, where three generations of characters burst forth in manic and frenetic displays of charm, confusion and chaos. The story is built around two old friends and their families who become impossibly entangled in a marriage of inconvenience. With a soundtrack of Gypsy music and songs, the funny film features numerous non-professional in the cast. In Serbo-Croation with English subtitles. Cast includes: Bajram Severdzan, Florijan Ajdini, Salija Ibraimova, Branka Katic and Srdjan Todorovic.

results.title: Black by popular demand: black and blue: black women in jazz and blues music.
results.brief_description: These two documentaries take a traditional approach to familiar subjects and rely for their impact on the strength of the stories they have to tell. ‘Tiny and Ruby: hell divin’ women’ (Producer Andrea Weiss, director Greta Schiller) evokes the masculine milieu of the American jazz scene that two marginalised women have managed to succeed in. ‘Wild women don’t have the blues’ (Producers Carol Doyle Van Vallenburgh) mixes the oral history of now veteran performers with archive footage, old photographs and sound recordings to revise male-oriented preconceptions around development of the blues. Both stories are set against an economic and social context in which black people were far from equal, emphasising the strength, determination and sheer power of women who live on their music. This compilation will appeal not only to those interested in blues and jazz, but is also a good example for cinema studies for it’s documentary, drama and animation style.
results.title_for_label: Black by popular demand: black and blue: black women in jazz and blues music.

results.title: Black books [the complete 1st series]
results.brief_description: In the tradition of hilarious British comedy, “Black books” offers its social insights via a campaign of acerbic one-liners and surreal plot devices. Bernard Black (Dylan Moran) is an Irish expatriate, London bookstore proprietor, and devoted alcoholic. From his introduction in Episode One, ushering customers out of his shop with broom and megaphone, we know these are the antics of the arch-misanthrope of recent television. Joining Bernard is his drinking partner Fran (Tamsin Greig) and Manny (Bill Bailey), a hairy if naive newcomer to the absurd business practices of Black Books. These first six episodes are a fine solution to the stodgy formula of popular US comedy.
